Is there a way to tell if my crickets are properly dried BEFORE I entomb them?
23 replies · last active 4h ago

@chirp_embalmer — I lost a beautiful piece to internal condensation. Three months in, the thorax just... gave up. Clouded the whole left quadrant.

@resin_rick

Snap test. If a leg breaks clean, it's dry. If it bends, give it another 48 hours in silica gel. I've been doing this for six years and have never lost a cricket.

Disclaimers & FAQ

Why is my piece turning yellow? ▾

This is the single most asked question on ResinRepos and it deserves a prominent answer.

UV exposure causes amine yellowing in most two-part epoxy systems. It is not a defect in your art — it is a property of the material. Your grandmother's buttons are fine. The resin around them is aging, as all things do. UV-resistant formulations slow but do not prevent this. We recommend displaying pieces away from direct sunlight, or accepting that time will add its own amber filter to your memories. Some of our users consider this a feature.

Why was my "Preserved Ham Sandwich" submission removed? ▾

Your ham sandwich was removed not because it was a ham sandwich — we have 14 successfully listed charcuterie-in-resin pieces — but because the AI critic flagged it as "a sandwich someone forgot on a break room counter, then panicked and poured resin over to hide the evidence." The composition suggested no intentional preservation. The mustard distribution was chaotic. We encourage you to resubmit with a statement of artistic intent. We will not accept "I just really liked that sandwich" a third time.

Content Policy: Accidental Nudity in Found Object Resin Art ▾

ResinRepos recognizes that found objects embedded in resin may occasionally include items depicting or suggesting nudity (vintage postcards, anatomical diagrams, small figurines in states of undress, etc.). Such content is permitted provided it meets all three criteria: (1) the nudity is incidental to the artistic purpose of the piece; (2) the embedded object was not manufactured after 2005; and (3) the submitter certifies the nudity was discovered, not engineered. Pieces featuring deliberately arranged nudity must be tagged [ANATOMICAL] and will receive AI critique with clinical detachment only. No exceptions have been requested. We are prepared regardless.

What is the "Certified Critic" badge? ▾

The Certified Critic badge is awarded to users whose submissions have received an overall AI assessment score above 8.2 across a minimum of 12 pieces. It does not mean the AI likes you. It means the AI has found consistent evidence of compositional intent, material awareness, and what it calls "emotional coherence" — a metric we did not program and cannot fully explain. There are currently 23 Certified Critics. Most of them are surprised.

Can I embed human remains? ▾

Cremation ashes: yes, with documentation. Hair: yes. Teeth: case-by-case basis — submit a materials form. Other biological material: please email legal@resinrepos.com with a description no longer than 200 words. We have found that if you need more than 200 words to explain what it is, we probably cannot list it. The AI critic will assess these pieces with the same rigor applied to all submissions. It does not know what it is looking at. This is by design.
